I was over-exited with the 100%. Turkey‚Äôs issue with Finland and Sweden having been long providing refuge to PKK terrorists is bound to have popular support at home. Erdogan doesn‚Äôt have the support of close to half the population, but a big chunk of them would agree with Ankara‚Äôs stance on this. Will need to look into local media coverage, but this is a winning issue for Erdogan and the AKP, IMO. Of course, Turkey‚Äôs self-inflicted economic troubles will strengthen NATO‚Äôs hand in the negotiations. I don‚Äôt expect Erdogan to hold out too long, although for the MHP (nationalist) component of his coalition this could be a central issue.

When your application is accepted for processing, you have completed a step in the admission process. When you applied to university, there were several reasons they might have refused to accept your application: You may have neglected to send a cheque in the correct amount; you may have omitted basic information; you may be on a list of people whose applications were by God not going to be considered. There is no doubt that some states have in the past been discouraged from even applying to join NATO, so accepting an application and announcing the beginning of the members' review should constitute "formal progress" for this Q.

Finland is basically guaranteed to do this. Sweden is probable. Moldova and Georgia have very remote chances, as those moves would be geopolitically too complicated. Switzerland and Austria have no real need to join on short notice, unless the war situation changes. All in all: basically 100% guaranteed, unless some unforeseen circumstance prevents it.

"Finland will decide to apply for NATO membership on May 12, Finnish newspaper Iltalehti reported late on Sunday, citing anonymous government sources. The decision to join will come in two steps on that day, with Finnish President Sauli Niinisto first announcing his approval for the Nordic neighbour of Russia to join the Western defence alliance, followed by parliamentary groups giving their approval for the application, the paper reported."

" The main obstacle to Swedish membership has been the ruling Social Democrat party, which has long been ideologically opposed to Nato and wedded to Sweden‚Äôs 200 years of neutrality.Analysts said it was therefore highly significant that Aftonbladet, a tabloid partly owned by the trade union movement and seen as the house newspaper of the Social Democrats, published an editorial on Wednesday recommending Sweden join Nato.Anders Lindberg, political editor at the newspaper, said it had a ' little reluctantly ' changed its opinion.' I do not really see how Sweden and Finland will be able to guarantee our security outside Nato when Russia is ready in 2022 to start completely unprovoked a full-scale war against a neighbouring country,' he wrote in the editorial.An opinion poll, also published in Aftonbladet on Wednesday, showed 57 per cent of Swedes were in favour of Nato membership and only 21 per cent against. Strikingly, it found for the first time a plurality of Social Democrats backing membership, with 41 per cent in favour and 25 per cent against."
Candidates Finland and Sweden look promising. Although the timescale of the process and behavior of some current NATO-members (Hungary) contain insecurities.

really shocking what a foreign policy blunder the invasion has been for Russia.
With Finland and Sweden racing to possibly join NATO, the layout has changed.

Russian response has been far weaker and less impactful than I expected, even as they start to reach for nuclear weapons deployments in the Baltic. I guess they are even more focused on Ukraine and less capable than I thought. [[ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-warns-baltic-nuclear-deployment-if-nato-admits-sweden-finland-2022-04-14/ ]] With both Sweden and Finland now looking at accession, it will be more difficult to block dialogue from starting. I was a little surprised at how effective Finnish dialogue with Sweden was at immediately pushing Sweden to NATO -- I thought it would have been on the ballot but I guess the ruling party wants to cut it off early. I may also have been downplaying the credibility of Stoltenberg/NATO leadership, and statements from the US which state there are no countries opposed to accession. While I still would prefer statements from each nation's leadership, I am increasingly thinking NATO/US statements of no opposition are a reasonable proxy for other country's NATO representatives. I also believe that the leverage from any single country gets stronger the further down the process, so any disruption would be focused on blocking final accession rather than initial dialogue. Uncomfortably putting yes at 98%.
The only thing I can think of that would stop it at this point is some procedural hiccup unknown to me. Public/political opinion is not going to reverse at this point.

Expanding NATO is a big bugbear to Putin and he uses NATO growth in his domestic information dogma, yet if NATO aspiring countries only advance in ‚Äòacceptance levels‚Äô, but not reach full membership invitation status, I think Putin will not raise his bets in the great poker game of ‚Äòwill he won‚Äôt he‚Äô use any form of nuclear weapons. The West will hold their nerve and continue supplying a higher grade of weapons to Ukraine. Not a very clean domestic message to the Russian people.

(no change) Whether one agrees or disagrees, this makes a fascinating look back:

Finland getting on Stoltenberg‚Äôs magic bus it seems‚Ä¶ also the fact that they have been talking to other countries about providing security commitments during accession process means that this is being taken seriously.

As of 2022, NATO officially recognizes three states which have formally expressed their membership aspirations: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, and Ukraine. We all know that recently several other countries outside the alliance, such as Finland, Ireland, Moldova, Serbia, and Sweden, expressed interest in joining NATO. However, I doubt that any of those countries would do so at this delicate moment in history. Besides, the process is long, and at present NATO has other matters to deal with.

Neither NATO nor the government of any aspirant country has the current bandwidth to deal with NATO accession procedures. Further, the relevant governments have little interest in further provoking Russia. Current cooperation structures either will or won't prevent further hostilities.
Sweden or Finland are highly likely to do it.

Swedish PM has reversed stance and is no longer outright against joining NATO. [1] My guess is this is a reaction to Finland's continued pro-NATO movement, because the two countries have strongly linked security policies. Danish PM would support Finland's NATO membership. [2] New poll for Finland at +61/-16, i.e., support is not falling unlike in the 2014 Crimean conflict. [3] Finland's party leaders are being given additional influence in the NATO process [4,5]. Not sure if this changes much, except I suppose the Center party's leadership may be less in favour of NATO than most of its MPs. Niinisto has backed away from a referendum or large opinion poll, so that step is probably dead now [6]. This means that NATO accession will be decided in parliament. ----- [1] https://www.thelocal.se/20220330/swedens-pm-i-do-not-rule-out-nato-membership-in-any-way/ [2] https://www-mtvuutiset-fi.translate.goog/artikkeli/tanskan-paaministeri-tukisimme-suomen-nato-jasenyytta/8391258?_x_tr_sl=fi&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=sc [3] https://www-is-fi.translate.goog/kotimaa/art-2000008718751.html?_x_tr_sl=fi&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=sc [4] https://www-iltalehti-fi.translate.goog/politiikka/a/0b074484-97b4-431f-8cca-eefd07fc0878?_x_tr_sl=fi&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=sc [5] https://www-hs-fi.translate.goog/junkkari/art-2000008717277.html?_x_tr_sl=fi&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=sc [6] https://svenska-yle-fi.translate.goog/a/7-10014841?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=sc

(no change) There are 30 countries in NATO. Without too much lawyering, basically all have to sort of head in the same direction regarding accession. I find the concensus interesting, but my Brier shows I'm frequently wrong. ;-)

Finland may be well on its way to become a NATO member and NATO may wish to model how welcoming and non-threatening the process of a Russia-neighboring country effectively is, before the end of the year.

German Chancellor Scholz signals support for a Finnish NATO bid [1]. Remember he's SPD, formerly the party of engagement with Russia (e.g., Nordstream). A Finnish ex-commander of armed forces (once skeptical of NATO) now supports. [2] I think it's likely that this + the reserve officers poll suggests that the upcoming security report will lean pro-NATO and not be a downward shock. The pro-NATO view in the security establishment can also be see in the RKP/Swedish People's Party pro-NATO stance, since the RKP has had an unusually high number of foreign/defense ministers. Another center party MP has officially declared support for NATO. [3] Clearly shows that parties will split votes between leadership and members if some members in the leadership are anti-NATO, and that the Center is swinging to NATO.

Helpful comments laying out options from @sevedb [1] and many more detailed analyses of situations (especially in Finland) from @jdwh08 (most recently [2] [3] [4].) Finland seems the most likely to formally progress with NATO this year, with lesser chance of Sweden.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1417252

Finland tested the waters with existing NATO members, mentioning the polls and possibility of joining NATO [1]. Previous meetings with US, UK, Turkey are thus confirmed by foreign minister Haavisto to have been part of the alliance-testing needed before a NATO membership application. Through the Estonian PM, Finland could make a NATO decision in as short as a month [2]. Finnish PM's office does not support this claim. Leader of the Center party thinks that Ukraine's pro-NATO position was one reason it got invaded. Pro-NATO members have criticized this. [3,4] Seems like an strong emotional response & members are becoming less willing to hear realist geopolitical arguments. Leader of the SDP is still open and has acknowledged a shift towards NATO in the SDP. [4] Leader of the Greens has now stated pro-NATO. [5] Finnish PM Marin's speech compared the Russia-Ukraine war to the Winter War, suggests that NATO is a complement to the EU, the post-Cold War order is broken, and that Finland needs to consider how to increase its security. [6] Discussion mentioned the ambiguity of the NATO timeline (uncertain, possibly years from defense secretary Kaikkonen) and Russia's potential retaliation (a broad range, but does not mean Finland cannot make its own defense policy from PM Marin). -------- My projection on current NATO support in the Finnish Parliament: SDP - 40 seats, ~51% internal support, but party leadership will not officially back. Guessing ~15 yes votes (instead of ~20) Centre Party - 31 seats, 67% voter support, but current party head is against. Will be conservative and guess ~17 yes votes (instead of 20.77) Greens - 20 seats, 67% voter support, party head is for. Will guess ~15 yes votes (instead of 13.4 from voter share) Left Alliance - 16 votes. No. Swedish People's - 10 votes. Held a pro-NATO position before the invasion of Ukraine. Will guess 9 votes. (instead of all 10) Finns Party - 38 votes. Not much information, currently in debate, but leaning pro-NATO. Will guess 19 votes. (instead of 61%/25 votes.) National Conservatives - 38 votes. Held a pro-NATO position before the invasion of Ukraine. Will guess 36 votes. (instead of all 38) Christian Democrats - 5 votes. No information, but they're to the right of the National Conservatives. Will guess 3 votes (instead of all 5) Guessing the remaining two parties with 1 vote each will be a no (Movement Now could flip, but assume no) Even when being fairly conservative, I get 114/200 yes votes, which is a slim-to-moderate majority.
I can't picture anyone wanting to get flattened a la Ukraine.

New poll for Finland at +62% / -16% [1], up from +53%/-28% in mid-February. Poll of Finnish businesses & entrepreneurs at +66%. [1.1] Should be pretty clear that the Finnish people's opinion on NATO has changed. Slim majority in people who vote SDP (+51%), but massive swings in the Greens (to +67%) and clear majority from the Center (+67%). There's also declining support for a NATO referendum -- a referendum might delay NATO talks beyond 2022. Internal poll of the ruling SDP's members (not the general public) puts it at +57.4% / -42.6%. [1.2] Former NATO Secretary General Rasmussen (2009-2014) says Finland and Sweden could join NATO near overnight, but the window is "closing" so they should take fast action [2]. Former Finnish PM Alexander Stubb thinks Finland will apply to join NATO in months. [2.1] Admittedly, he is a conservative so leans that direction himself. Finnish president Niinisto continues meeting with key NATO allies to ensure security, this time the UK [3]. He's joined by the Swedish PM. NATO military drill in Norway with the US deploying a sizeable force. Sweden and Finland are participating. [4] March 18 - April 2. Because of the April 2 end date, it's not relevant, but shows clear defense cooperation. Would be interesting if the troops stayed around through the summer...
maintaining current forecast

Up 17% to be closer to the consensus. Still think realpolitik will prevail in 2022.

Three countries have declared their aspirations to NATO membership: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia and Ukraine. The Republic of North Macedonia became the latest country to join the Alliance on 27 March 2020.
The possibilities of reaching just a new stage in accession seem to be increasing.

Finnish military reserve officer poll on NATO: +83.1% / -9%, up from +64% before the invasion of Ukraine and +44.3% in 2020. [1] Clarification on the timeline for NATO consideration in Finland. [2] Government report due by April, ruling SDP will meet in 2 April, Basic Finns in 30 April, Greens in 21-22 May, Left in 10-12 May, Center in 10-12 June (though position will be resolved through the spring). The decision to join NATO will ultimately come down to parliament and thus these parties, but President Niinisto and PM Marin have a good deal of influence if they choose to speak up. Current status on the party positions [3]: Center and Swedish People's Party were long supporters of NATO. Greens and Finns party are quickly becoming in favour. Ruling SDP is divided, with PM Marin's actions hinting at a pro-NATO view but divisions in her party which would make it difficult. The Center party is split and going through debate. Based on the current Finnish parliament [4], NATO support would need around 50 members to switch sides towards yes. Splits in the Greens, Finns, and Center would be enough for a weak majority. Ideally it would be a strong majority though, so the majority in the Greens, Finns, and Center, along with some SDP. In my opinion, for Finland to support NATO requires 1) the government report / Niinisto to suggest NATO membership has more benefits than drawbacks, 2) split or majority votes in the currently deciding parties, 3) for the vote to happen in autumn or early winter which it seems on track for, and 4) for the government to continue its work in the background meeting with western partners to gauge security promises, which has been ongoing.
(no change) With nuclear options being batted about, I suspect everyone in the west will decide to hit pause related to things that might be provocative.

The only EU members that are note NATO members are: Austria, Cyprus, Ireland, and Malta, Finland and Sweden (https://www.wilsoncenter.org/article/sisters-not-twins-prospects-finland-and-swedens-nato-accession). Neither Finland or Sweden seem currently interested (previous citation). Nor does Austria (https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/austrians-torn-between-neutrality-and-nato-1.142643). All of the above consider themselves "military non-aligned." Three countries are moving through the ascension process: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia and Ukraine (https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_49212.htm). Of all the above, including non-aligned countries, B&H probably has the best chance of advancing the process of joining NATO. Discussions of ascension have stalled since 2018 and there are no reports of them beginning again in the wake of the invasion of Ukraine. However, there has been some discontent about Ukraine that might spur action (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accession_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_to_NATO; https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/bosnians-remembering-their-own-war-protest-support-ukraine-2022-02-25/). B&H still has some strong ethnic rivalries that need to be reduced prior to acceptance. Through December 2022 is a long enough time that I'll give it just under a 50/50 chance and see how things shake out in the next couple of months before I go lower.

While NATO leaders have the appearance of being caught off guard and scrambling to the negotiating table to avoid war at all costs, Putin is like an alligator. The problem with meeting any of Putin's concession demands is this: If you give a gator food, it'll get more aggressive and be more likely to attack in the future. If leaders are wise, they will read Putin's behavior as a predatory stance. How they deal with a predator is another kind of wisdom-- especially dealing with a predator with vast strategic arsenals of both military and asymmetric weapons that could wreak havoc on the planet.

Outside View: Based on NATO's timeline, qualifying enlargement post-Cold War happened in 1997, 1999, 2002, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, and 2020. That's ~>60% of years from 1997 to 2021. However, the number of countries has been decaying from 7 in 1997 to around 1-3 relevant countries in the late 2010s. NATO is running out of countries to add.
